entry.title: Tech News: Self Tracking, MindRDR, Streamfully, ...
entry.content:
1. The Next Big Programming Language you’ve never heard
  2. Phant : A place to push your data
  3. LifeTip : A fitness tracking device that doesn’t need skin contact
  4. Amazon Goes After Box, Dropbox And Huddle, Launches Zocalo For Secure Enterprise Storage
  5. Raspberry Pi Microcomputer Gets Beefed Up — Still Only Costs $35
  6. Linux tool to show progress for cp, rm, dd
  7. I track everything about myself
  8. MindRDR : A Google Glass App that lets you control it with your thoughts
  9. Streamfully Turns Web Links Into Personalized Content Previews
  10. Wink’s Connected Home Collection Arrives At Home Depot
  11. Tablo : A platform for self-publishing community
  12. Freble: A gadget that lets you hold hands online
  13. Pixotale: A Social Networking App for visual storytelling

External links :-

  1. Too much power for one man : An article on how Google and its CEO,Larry Page, practically own the world!
  2. Facebook’s solution to big data’s “content problem:” dumber users
  3. What I mean when I say, “I think VR is bad news”
  4. Bitly: Lessons Learned Building a Distributed System that Handles 6 Billion Clicks a Month
  5. What problems to solve: A letter by Richard Feynman to his former student
  6. Why I cancelled my Oculus Rift and You Should too; Because google cardboard proved it can do a better work cheaper and bette
  7. Android Wear needs to be more thoughtful about bugging you
  8. Timberman is the new Flappy Bird

   

  1. The Next Big Programming Language you’ve never heard of

    • D programming language got its name, although it was initially called Mars, because it was seen as a successor of C++.
    • It has been around for over 9 years and, unlike most new languages, has recently picked up momentum.
    • This can be attributed to Facebook deciding to experiment with the language.
    • The language tries to bridge the gap between languages like C++ and Python, i.e. the fast languages and easy languages.
    • Andrei Alexandrescu, one of the authors of the language, is a research scientist at Facebook where his team is trying to rewrite small parts of the company using D. Walter Bright, the other author, is also collaborating on this project as an outside contractor.

    • Other languages that try to bridge the gap between the two kinds of languages are Google’s Go Programming Language and Apple’s Swift

      “D is similar to C++, but better,” says Brad Anderson, a longtime C++ programmer from Utah who has been using D as well. “It’s high performance, but it’s expressive. You can get a lot done without very much code.”

    • Facebook is working on another language, Hack, which is also trying to bridge this gap. Hack has been used at Facebook to replace the frontend PHP code and can be seen as a new version of PHP itself. It allows developers to use both static and dynamic typing, also called gradual typing
    • While Hack currently replaces only the front-end at Facebook, D is being experimented for backend processes. However, its authors intend D to be the language of choice for all kinds of tasks.

  2. Phant : A place to push your data

    • data.sparkfun.com powered by Phant, provides a place to push your data streams.
    • This allows developers to send data from any device to the server which stores the data (up to 500MB, for free).
    • This will help developers and hackers ignore the problems around data storage and focus on applications that require several datapoints to be stored, shared and analyzed.
    • The idea is aimed at providing a platform to bring ‘Internet of things’ to reality.

    • How does it work :

      We thought data storage should be as easy as string concatenation. First, create a stream and you’ll receive a public url and a private key. Then, using the hardware of your choice (Ethernet shield, RasPi, BBB, Electric Imp, WiFly) simply create a string with the data you want to post.

    • The underlying engine, Phant, is open-sourced and can be setup on any box, giving developers control of their own data and allowing other such services to pop-up.

  3. LifeTip : A fitness tracking device that doesn’t need skin contact

    • Unlike wearables like FitBit, LifeTip doesn’t require to be in direct contact with the skin or body. It hooks into a woman’s bra or a man’s shirt and reads information like ECG (not just heart rate), calories burned and steps taken by the user.

    • The device is connected to a phone application using bluetooth, which receives the data and can be used to provide insights into it.

      Using capacitive technology, the device is able to measure all of these verticals without ever coming into contact with the skin, saving users from potential allergic reactions

    • This project was recently launched on Indiegogo, which is a platform like Kickstarter.

  4. Amazon Goes After Box, Dropbox And Huddle, Launches Zocalo For Secure Enterprise Storage

    • Amazon launched Zocalo which is a ‘fully managed, secure enterprise storage and sharing service with strong administrative controls and feedback capabilities that improve user productivity’.

    • It lets users “store, share, and gather feedback on documents, spreadsheets, presentations, webpages, images, PDFs, or text files – from the device of their choice.”

    • By providing this service, Amazon has entered into the competition against the likes of Box and Dropbox. Although there are several players in this segment, Amazon seems to be focusing on problems faced by users in using these services.

    • The focus lies on :-
      • Easy sharing
      • Any device access
      • Available with Amazon WorkSpaces
      • Simple Feedback
      • Central file hub
    • The pricing is quite aggressive. Moreover, WorkSpaces customers will get access to Zocalo for free - including 50 GB of storage per WorkSpaces user

  5. Raspberry Pi Microcomputer Gets Beefed Up — Still Only Costs $35

    • Raspberry Pi launched a new model called B+.
    • Improvements
      • More USB - 4 instead of 2.
      • MicroSD slot replacing the SD card slot.
      • Lower power consumption
      • Improved audio
    • The new model is available today.

  6. Linux tool to show progress for cp, rm, dd, …

    • What is it?

      This tool can be described as a Tiny Dirty Linux Only C command that looks for coreutils basic commands (cp, mv, dd, tar, gzip/gunzip, cat, …) currently running on your system and displays the percentage of copied data.

    • How does it work?

      It simply scans /proc for interesting commands, and then use fd/ and fdinfo/ directories to find opened files and seek position, and reports status for the biggest file.

  7. I track everything about myself

    • A website by Anand Sharma, living in San Fransisco, displaying all that he has tracked about himself.

      This site tracks where I go and what I do every day. Most of the data comes from various apps on my phone.

    • Tracking is done using apps and tools like Moves, Nike Plus, Mapbox, Github, Foursquare, etc.

    • Things that are tracked :-

      • Fitness related :
        • Heart rate, weight and body fat
        • Glucose level, HDL, LDL, Sodium, Iron, Potassium, etc.
        • Miles run, calories burned, steps walked, etc.
      • Locations and countries visited
      • Miles traveled

  8. MindRDR : A Google Glass App that lets you control it with your thoughts

    • The app links Google Glass with another head mounted hardware, the Neurosky EEG biosensor, to create a communication loop

      The Neurosky biosensor picks up on brainwaves that correlate to your ability to focus. The app then translates these brainwaves into a meter reading that gets superimposed on the camera view in Google Glass. As you “focus” more with your mind, the meter goes up, and the app takes a photograph of what you are seeing in front of you. Focus some more, and the meter goes up again and the photo gets posted to Twitter.

    • It was created by a team out of This Place interactive studio, which has been working on user interface.

    • Very early stages; clumsy prototype and not yet ready for production.

      The idea here is that this is a minimum viable product, a first step that can be developed further — for example, to create applications to “train” people to concentrate better, or to play games, maybe to help suggest places to get a coffee when your sensor picks up that you’re tired, or for medical applications, for example for people with mobility problems.

      And potentially, you could build out the basic concept with more, lighter and easier-to-use sensors. This Place says that among those who have taken an interest are Stephen Hawking, the famous physicist who is nearly paralysed because of a progressive motor neuron disease.

      MindRDR from This Place Ltd on Vimeo.

  9. Streamfully Turns Web Links Into Personalized Content Previews

    • On installing Streamfully Chrome Extension, every time the user hovers over a link, she can view a preview of the page which would contain snippets and images from the page.

    • The snippets are aimed to be user-specific, based on the content it deems relevant to the user.

    • This could help user identify if the page in discussion contains information she is looking for.

      Pangaro [the creator] suggested that this moves web pages and articles away from being “giant containers” and makes the reading experience “more conversational” — in other words, more relevant to your interests, less repetitive (since Streamfully will focus on what’s unique about a piece of content and what it hasn’t shown you in other previews), and with more of a “dance and flow.”

      And it necessarily mean it will be shallower experience, either — Pangaro said that by since it has lowered “the bio cost of looking” (i.e., the annoyance of clicking on a page and discovering that it isn’t what you were looking for), Streamfully might actually encourage users to spend more time with content once they know it’s a good fit.

    • Chrome extension is free and Pangaro plans to generate revenue through ads and by offering this as a tool to publishers.

  10. Wink’s Connected Home Collection Arrives At Home Depot

    • Wink is another player in the home automation segment.

    • Its app allows the user to control and monitor several home appliances through their smartphones (iOS or Android).

    • They have, now, released a list of compatible products which are now available across several locations in the US.

      The Wink platform is basically a central hub for devices from manufacturers, including Dropcam, Honeywell, Quirky, Schalge, Kwikset and more, giving users a single app for either iOS or Android from which to customize and control them all.

  11. Tablo : A platform for self-publishing community

    • Founded by Ashley Davies; raised $400,000 from Y Combinator partner Kevin Hale and Paul Reining

    • Focuses on intuitive and nice interface. Allows users to publish instantly, like while publishing a blog.

      “As a blogger I was so used to being able to type something and click a publish button,” said Davies. “I wanted to change this and give emerging authors a place where they can easily create, share, and connect with readers. Publishing a book with Tablo is as easy as publishing a blog and, when you finish writing, you’ll have an established readership.

      The service currently has 10,000 authors from 100 countries. Each author has a social profile on the site and authors can invite readers to follow them as they flesh out their books. The service offers a seamless, non-intrusive interface based around the book editor that allows you to enter text and publish it immediately. Book chapters appear as “posts” in the service and users can read them or subscribe to updates.

  12. Freble: A gadget that lets you hold hands online

    • Using haptic technology, Frebles provides the sensation of holding hands.

      Haptic technology built into the Frebble is designed to imitate the feeling of holding someone’s hand. Two pressure sensors on the front pick up on squeezing while two vibration motors and a “squeeze bar” provide the sensation of squeezing back. The bar is like a little lever that extends against the back of your hand. A package of two Frebbles is going for a $99 pledge.

    • Project on Kickstarter

  13. Pixotale: A Social Networking App for visual storytelling

    • Pixotale is aimed at sharing longer stories with friends and family, instead of small status updates.

    • Moreover, it is designed to make it easier to create such long stories on mobile phones.

    • Created by former Microsoft engineers.

    • Examples of such stories :-

      • Why I cancelled my Oculus Rift and You Should too; Because google cardboard proved it can do a better work cheaper and bette
      • SeaWorld Orlando
      • The Most Bloody Infographic About Dictators

entry.title: Tech News: Xiki, Inbox, Oculus Connect, ...
entry.content:
1. Xiki: The command revolution by Craig Muth
  2. Oculus announces Oculus Connect, acquires RakNet and Open Sources its technology
  3. Inbox : A next generation email platform
  4. Hospitals Are Mining Patients’ Credit Card Data to Predict Who Will Get Sick
  5. Plants Respond to Leaf Vibrations Caused by Insects’ Chewing, MU Study Finds
  6. SecureDrop

External links :-

  1. Sheetlabs : Turn your spreadsheets into APIs effortlessly
  2. Python is now the most popular introductory teaching language at top U.S. universities [Related : Python Tutor]


  1. Xiki: The command revolution by Craig Muth

    • Xiki, something the author has been working on for 10 years, aims to discard the conventional command execution and replace that will an interactive command line tool.

    • While the previous version of Xiki is available and open sourced, Craig Muth is Kickstarting a new, improved version

    If this campaign succeeds, the money will let me dedicate the time needed to bring this next, drastically improved, version of Xiki to the world. Xiki plugins for Sublime and Vim will be created. The installer and initial user experience will be greatly improved (largely by adding contextual menus everywhere). The integration with the shell will be improved. To enable supporting new Xiki plugins, the core of Xiki will be refactored. It will do the heavy lifting so the plugins will no longer have to.

  2. Oculus announces Oculus Connect, acquires RakNet and Open Sources its technology

    • RakNet is a cross-platform C++ network engine for game development.

      The tech is tuned for cross-platform, high-performance applications that operate across a wide variety of network types. Key features include object replication, remote procedure calls, patching, secure connections, voice chat, and real-time SQL logging. The technology has been licensed by thousands of indie developers, as well as companies like Unity, Havok, Mojang, Maxis and Sony Online Entertainment.

    • After using it internally for quite some time, Oculus has now open sourced RakNet under BSD License.

    • They announced their own developer conference Oculus Connect “that brings together engineers, designers, and creatives from around the world to share and collaborate in the interest of creating the best virtual reality experiences possible.”

    • Oculus Connect is scheduled for September 19-20 and attendee applications will open on July 10th.

    • It would be a great conference for all those interested in VR, especially in Oculus’s products.

      Attendees will be the first to learn about upcoming Oculus technology, with sessions and workshops led by Oculus engineers and industry pioneers. Developers at the event will also have opportunities to receive design and engineering feedback directly from the Oculus team in hands-on labs.

  3. Inbox : A next generation email platform

    • The core idea of Inbox is to help developers exploit email as a platform without the hassles of archaic protocols like IMAP and SMTP.

      “I actually wrote my thesis at MIT on email tools, and discovered how difficult it was to add features to email apps,” explains Grinich [co-founded] of how Inbox came to be. “One big issue was the underlying plumbing – IMAP, MIME, character encodings, etc. – which is what Inbox fixes for developers.”

    • Inbox provide REST APIs to retrieve, modify and send emails. It also provides APIs for complex tasks like custom filtering, accessing attachments, creating drafts, etc.

    • Javascript and iOS SDKs are already available.

    • Founded by MIT Alums.

      The company was co-founded by MIT alums, Michael Grinich, previously an engineer at Dropbox and designer Nest, and Christine Spang, an early Linux kernel engineer at Ksplice (acquired by Oracle.) The core team at Inbox also includes several other MIT alums, plus those with experience from Google and Firebase, as well as two graduates from the Parallel and Distributed Operating Systems group at MIT CSAIL, which spun out Meraki (acquired by Cisco).

    • The company would also provide fundamental infrastructure as an open source package.

  4. Hospitals Are Mining Patients’ Credit Card Data to Predict Who Will Get Sick

    • Carolina Healthcare Systems is buying credit-card data of its customers to be able to better predict the chances of them getting ill and provide them with relevant care and advice before that happens.

    • By tracking expenses, they hope to be able to get insights into their habits. This can provide much more information than can be attained by the little time the doctor gets to assess a patient.

      For a patient with asthma, the hospital would be able to assess how likely he is to arrive at the emergency room by looking at whether he’s refilled his asthma medication at the pharmacy, has been buying cigarettes at the grocery store, and lives in an area with a high pollen count, Dulin says. The system may also look at the probability of someone having a heart attack by considering factors such as the type of foods she buys and if she has a gym membership. “The idea is to use Big Data and predictive models to think about population health and drill down to the individual levels,” he says.

    • While the supporters argue that such data is already used to targetted advertising and this is a much better use of the same information, there are a lot of privacy concerns around the use of data for health tracking and unsolicited help.

      “It is one thing to have a number I can call if I have a problem or question; it is another thing to get unsolicited phone calls. I don’t like that,” says Jorjanne Murry, an accountant in Charlotte who has Type 1 diabetes and says she usually ignores calls from her health insurer trying to discuss her daily habits. “I think it is intrusive.”

  5. Plants Respond to Leaf Vibrations Caused by Insects’ Chewing, MU Study Finds

    • The study

      • Caterpillars were placed on Arabidopsis, a small flowering plant related to cabbage and mustard and the movement of the leaf in response to the chewing was measured and recorded, using a laser and a tiny piece of reflective material on the leaf of the plant.

      • Recordings of caterpillar feeding vibrations were played back to a set of plants, while only silence was played back on the other.

      • Caterpillars were later fed on these plants.

    • Findings

      • The plants previously exposed to feeding vibrations produced more mustard oils, a chemical that is unappealing to many caterpillars.

      “What is remarkable is that the plants exposed to different vibrations, including those made by a gentle wind or different insect sounds that share some acoustic features with caterpillar feeding vibrations did not increase their chemical defenses,” Cocroft said. “This indicates that the plants are able to distinguish feeding vibrations from other common sources of environmental vibration.”

    • How can it be used?

    “Caterpillars react to this chemical defense by crawling away, so using vibrations to enhance plant defenses could be useful to agriculture,” Appel said. “This research also opens the window of plant behavior a little wider, showing that plants have many of the same responses to outside influences that animals do, even though the responses look different.”

  6. SecureDrop

    • SecureDrop, by Washington Post, is a discreet way to share messages and materials with their journalists.

    • While it doesn’t claim to be perfect, it claims to offer greater security and anonymity than conventional e-mail and Web forms by minimizing digital trails left by the communication between the provider and Washington Post.

    • It relies on Tor and requires the user to access http://vbmwh445kf3fs2v4.onion, preferably using a Tor browser. From the URL, the user would be able to upload documents to a ‘secure dropbox’ which is periodically checked.

    • The URL also provides a codename to log in and check for replies.

      Keep the codename you are provided safe and secure. We will not know your codename, and you should never share it with anyone. If you forget your codename, we will have no other way to contact you.

entry.title: Tech News: Updates from the past week
entry.content:
1. Facebook’s experiment with user’s emotions and Ethics in a Data Driven world
  2. Stuxnet-Like Malware From Russia Is Attacking U.S. Power Plants
  3. Russia Moves To Ban Online Services That Don’t Store Personal Data In Russia
  4. Adblock Plus gives Facebook users a way to block its extended tracking efforts

External Links :-

  1. Consciousness on-off switch discovered deep in brain
  2. How a Russian Mathematician constructed a decision tree by hand to sovle a medical problem
  3. Rob Pike’s 5 Rules of Programming
  4. Pipes Is A Clever App That Lets You Track Any Topic You Care About
  5. BitAuth, for decentralized authentication
  6. NSA targets the Privacy Conscious (Another Article)

   

  1. Facebook’s experiment with user’s emotions and Ethics in a Data Driven World

    • In a recently published study by Facebook : Experimental evidence of massive-scale emotional contagion through social networks, they disclosed that for a week in 2012 they experimented with a set of ~700k English speaking users, such that some had posts with negative emotions deprioritized, while some had those with emotions deprioritized.

    • The experiment was aimed at exploring the impact of the emotional nature of the posts in the feed on the behavior and emotions of the user.

    • This has caused a huge stir in the media and has raised questions about the ethics of A/B testing.

    • While some argue that Facebook didn’t have the rights to perform such a test, by accepting their terms and conditions we agree to let them use our data in this form.

    • Moreover, this is not the first time a company has conducted an A/B test on its users. While in most other cases, the tests are aimed at finding the environment which gets the best returns, even they can be interpreted as a ‘psychological experiment’.

    • Response by Facebook’s employee, Adam Kramer (one of the authors of the paper)

      OK so. A lot of people have asked me about my and Jamie and Jeff’s recent study published in PNAS, and I wanted to give a brief public explanation. The reason we did this research is because we care about the emotional impact of Facebook and the people that use our product. We felt that it was important to investigate the common worry that seeing friends post positive content leads to people feeling negative or left out. At the same time, we were concerned that exposure to friends’ negativity might lead people to avoid visiting Facebook. We didn’t clearly state our motivations in the paper.

      Regarding methodology, our research sought to investigate the above claim by very minimally deprioritizing a small percentage of content in News Feed (based on whether there was an emotional word in the post) for a group of people (about 0.04% of users, or 1 in 2500) for a short period (one week, in early 2012). Nobody’s posts were “hidden,” they just didn’t show up on some loads of Feed. Those posts were always visible on friends’ timelines, and could have shown up on subsequent News Feed loads. And we found the exact opposite to what was then the conventional wisdom: Seeing a certain kind of emotion (positive) encourages it rather than suppresses is.

      And at the end of the day, the actual impact on people in the experiment was the minimal amount to statistically detect it — the result was that people produced an average of one fewer emotional word, per thousand words, over the following week.

      The goal of all of our research at Facebook is to learn how to provide a better service. Having written and designed this experiment myself, I can tell you that our goal was never to upset anyone. I can understand why some people have concerns about it, and my coauthors and I are very sorry for the way the paper described the research and any anxiety it caused. In hindsight, the research benefits of the paper may not have justified all of this anxiety.

      While we’ve always considered what research we do carefully, we (not just me, several other researchers at Facebook) have been working on improving our internal review practices. The experiment in question was run in early 2012, and we have come a long way since then. Those review practices will also incorporate what we’ve learned from the reaction to this paper

    • According to their study, there was a measurable, however small, impact on the users and there was a network effect( those who felt more negatively because of their feed shared negative feelings and passed on the effect).

    • While it is unclear how severe the impact was, it would be disastrous for Facebook’s reputation if it is discovered that their study resulted in serious consequences.

  2. Stuxnet-Like Malware From Russia Is Attacking U.S. Power Plants

    • The malware, dubbed ‘Energetic Bear’, targets energy and utility companies.

    • The attack has been going on for 18 months

      According to the Financial Times, the malware “allows its operators to monitor energy consumption in real time, or to cripple physical systems such as wind turbines, gas pipelines and power plants at will.”

    • Capabilities of the malware :
      • Access information on the victim’s computer networks
      • Steal data, collect passwords, take screenshots and even download and run files

      Symantec, the makers of the Norton suite, says the malware’s “main motive appears to be cyberespionage” but doesn’t mention any major shutdowns
      …
      Symantec says that the attackers—who they call Dragonfly—is almost certainly “based in eastern Europe and has all the markings of being state-sponsored.” Markers in the malware, like timestamps and Cyrillic, suggest that it originated in Russia.

    • About Stuxnet

      • Back in June 2010, Stuxnet was discovered and it was blamed for the decimation of Iranian nuclear facilities.

      • Until Snowden confirmed the suspicion, there were speculations that the worm was created by USA and Israel.

      • Stuxnet not only had the ability to jump inconspicuously from computer to computer, until it founds its way into the nuclear facilities’ network, but it could also mutate itself to avoid detection.

      • Once inside the required computers, it could manipulate motors at the facilities to make the spin faster than they should and also ensure that no alarm was raised because of it.

  3. Russia Moves To Ban Online Services That Don’t Store Personal Data In Russia

    … the Russian State Duma (parliament) passed the first bill requiring that the personal data of all Russians should be stored inside the country.

    • As a consequence of the bill, post September 2016, services like Facebook, Google or any international service would have to host their servers within Russian borders.

      Furthermore, these non-Russian companies would not be allowed to send data outside the country unless they can provide certain guarantees on data storage inside the country. For those who do not, the state telecommunications agency Roskomnadzor will require carriers to restrict access to those services.

      The bill also proposes amendments to laws covering personal information and data protection.

    • China is known to impose such restrictions on the Internet. While earlier it was seen as an opposition to free speech, now it can be easily justified as a move to protect the data from evesdropping by NSA.
    • Not only is this an indication of the tightening of regulations around the Internet around the world, but also how revelations of NSA’s snooping is affecting those regulations. Such regulations will severely impact the operations of the companies involved and could lead to further tougher laws restricting freedom of speech.

  4. Adblock Plus gives Facebook users a way to block its extended tracking efforts

    • Recently, Facebook announced
      that to be able to deliver ads to the users, it would track their activities across the web.

    • Although Facebook offers a way to opt-out, the terms aren’t very clear and it looks like a temporary solution.

    • Adblock Plus will now provide an option to allow its users to disable tracking by Facebook by using the social media tracking blocker

    Like the idea of FB tracking you? Yeah, that's what we thought. Here is a way out: https://t.co/VQODuPZwo1 pic.twitter.com/eMx34aX8Ed

    — Adblock Plus (@AdblockPlus) June 25, 2014

These would attempt to cover topics ranging from impressive apps to Google’s latest acquisition to jaw-dropping updates from SpaceX or Tesla Motors and much more.

entry.title: Tech News: Bitstamped, ClearTax, OnionShare,...
entry.content:
1. Bitstamped
  2. Project Ara and Tango updates at Google I/O
  3. Security Researchers Uncover The Tools Governments Use To Spy On Our Phones
  4. How Can Chromecast Connect To Your Friend’s Phones Without Using WiFi? Ultrasonic Sounds
  5. Onionshare : A tool to share files securely and anonymously
  6. YC-backed ClearTax tackles Indian’s fast growing online tax filing market
  7. Grasswire – an Internet newsroom curated and fact-checked by everyone
  8. Yo! Hackathon Attempts To Show How Yo Can Grow

External links:

  1. Micro-g Project : Aims to provide a free, fully compatible replacement of the often used proprietary GAPPS package by Google.
  2. The worst programming interview question: An article on why questions like ‘Write a function that can detect a cycle in a linked list’ are inappropriate for an interview.
  3. Material world: how Google discovered what software is made of

   

  1. Bitstamped
    • Provides a publicly verifiable timestamp that can be added to printed documents using a QR code.

    • It can be used to show that someone came up with an idea first.

      We don’t know if it’ll stand up in court, but for informal mediation of disputes, this might be useful.

    • This is an application of the Bitcoin protocol to establish ‘ownership’.
    • The uploaded file is used to create a SHA256 digest, which is then stored in blockchain, Bitcoin-protocol’s way of storing some information forever in a shared manner.

    • Bitstamp uses Proof of Existence API to create a service for the less technically inclined.

      We didn’t invent timestamping checksums on the Blockchain; our objective is to provide an easy to use interface to complete that task and provide a service for users to print a verifiable timestamp on their documents.

    • The file could either be shared or kept private (or shared at a later point). The file is stored on Amazon S3 storage service.
  2. Project Ara and Tango updates at Google I/O
    • Google’s Advanced Technology and Projects lab provided some interesting updates to Project Ara and Project Tango
    • Project Ara, that began as a concept called (and propogated by) PhoneBloks aiming to create a smartphone with modular units allowing for increased customization and longer life of phones.
    • At Google I/O, a prototype of a phone by Project Ara was unveiled

      When Eremenko brought the prototype on stage during a breakout session of Google I/O at San Francisco’s Moscone Center and flashed the Android bootup screen, the audience went wild.   3. Security Researchers Uncover The Tools Governments Use To Spy On Our Phones
    • Researchers from Kaspersky and Citizen Lab published research on a new type of malware designed to give police complete access to a suspect’s phone.

    • Remote Control System (RCS)/Galileo allows for full control of the data on the phone and allows listeners/police to activate the microphone on Android, iOS and Blackberry devices.

      The major exploits included access to the following phone features and apps:
      Control of Wi-Fi, GPS, GPRS
      Recording voice
      E-mail, SMS, MMS
      Listing files
      Cookies
      Visited URLs
      Cached web pages
      Address book
      Call history
      Notes
      Calendar
      Clipboard
      List of apps
      SIM change
      Live microphone
      Camera shots
      Support chats, WhatsApp, Skype, Viber
      Log keystrokes from all apps and screens via libinjection

    • Installing it on iOS requires a jailbroken phone, however it can be installed on Android without any root privileges.
    • The app was made by a Milan-based company, Hacking Team that has made a niche for itself selling surveillance software to police in several countries.

    • While its still unclear where RCS is currently used but researchers identified a piece of RCS software in a trojan horse that appears like an Arabic news reader, making a fake ‘Qatif’ news app used in Saudi Arabia.

      Hacking Team says it won’t sell its products to governments that are blacklisted by NATO, but critics say the company’s tools have already been used against pro-democracy Moroccan journalists and at least one American citizen.

    • Edward Snowden had pointed out that government had methods to remotely hack a user’s phone and spy on the user.

  4. How Can Chromecast Connect To Your Friend’s Phones Without Using WiFi? Ultrasonic Sounds
    • In Google I/O, it was announced that Chromecast would allow anyone in the same room to share the screen without requiring them to be on the same wifi.
    • In a post keynote presentation, it was cleared up that this was achieved using Ultrasonic soundwaves.
    • Once configured, Chromecast will push uniquely generated ultrasonic waves through the TV’s speakers encoding information required by the phone to pair up.
    • Apps using Chromecast SDK will listen for these ultrasounds (relying on the phone’s microphone) to detect and show the option to pair up with Chromecast.
    • Earlier this year, Google had acquired SlickLogin, which used ultrasonic soundwaves to provide something like a 2-factor authentication.
  5. Onionshare : A tool to share files securely and anonymously

    • How does it work?

      OnionShare lets you securely and anonymously share a file of any size with someone. It works by starting a web server, making it accessible as a Tor hidden service, and generating an unguessable URL to access and download the file. It doesn’t require setting up a server on the internet somewhere or using a third party filesharing service. You host the file on your own computer and use a Tor hidden service to make it temporarily accessible over the internet. The other user just needs to use Tor Browser to download the file from you.

    • If the file being sent is secret, one would want to use a secret way to send over the aforementioned URL and Off-the-Record encrypted chat is recommended for that.

  6. YC-backed ClearTax tackles Indian’s fast growing online tax filing market
    • ClearTax, founded in 2011 and based in Delhi, already has a strong presence in India automating the income tax filing process for workers.
    • Over 300,00 people used ClearTax last year to file their taxes.
    • First company to join YCombinator that focuses on only the Indian market.

    • It is not a typical Y Combinator launch

      While their market opportunity is currently in India, ClearTax decided to join Y Combinator because the startup got access to “a set of resources we don’t get in India,” says founder Archit Gupta.

      “We were missing some of the mentorship in India for example. I worked in Silicon Valley before. I was an engineer at Data Domain, which was acquired by EMC. So I had seen how being in the Valley is super useful, so that whole thing made it very, very clear to us that we should come out here.”

    • Two of the cofounders, Anupam Mediratta and Archit Gupta, graduated from IIT Guwahati, while the third, RR Gupta, is a CA by profession with decades of experience in taxation and accounting
    • There are several companies in India that offer online tax services.

    • ClearTax, however, follows a freemium model where they can file their taxes for free but pay to consult tax experts to get help on saving and filing.

      To use ClearTax, all someone needs to do is upload the form onto the website. Then ClearTax’s software automatically pulls out relevant data, so users don’t have to manually key in any numbers or information, and prepares tax forms for each user, a process the startup says can take as little as 15 minutes.
      Gupta says ClearTax’s main competitor is the government, which has its own online filing software, but that’s complicated to use, especially since people need to figure out which one out of seven tax forms they need to fill out

  8. Yo! Hackathon Attempts To Show How Yo Can Grow
    • Yo! made a lot of news recently when it received $1.2m in funding based on this app that sends across only a two letter word, ‘Yo!’.
    • The two-and-half hour hackathon was an attempt to prove that Yo could do much more than just send ‘Yo’ across to friends.
    • Using its API, people tried to create several apps.
    • Apps developed during the hackathon :-
      • YoServerIsDown allows users to sign up for this service which will send a ‘Yo’ whenever their server is down.
      • YOaster sends a ‘Yo’ when the toaster has finished toasting the bread.
      • Yo Radio bookmarks songs playing on the radio so a user can access information about the song later from a computer

    • As we can see from the above ideas, ‘Yo’ can meaning anything.

      Venture investor (and husband of one of the world’s best-dressed billionaires) Marc Andreessen calls yo an example of one-bit communication – a message that only exists as itself. There is no meaning — the medium is, in fact, the message.
